net.trajano.auth

Class OAuthModule

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.trajano.auth.OAuthModule
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    javax.security.auth.message.config.ServerAuthContext, javax.security.auth.message.module.ServerAuthModule, javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    GoogleAuthModule, OpenIDConnectAuthModule

    public abstract class OAuthModule
extends Object
implements javax.security.auth.message.module.ServerAuthModule, javax.security.auth.message.config.ServerAuthContext
    OAuth 2.0 server authentication module. This is an implementation of the OAuth 2.0 authentication framework. This assumes no HttpSessions which makes it useful for RESTful applications and uses the OAuth token to manage the authentication state. The e-mail addresses are not requested.
    Author:
    Archimedes Trajano

      • NET_TRAJANO_AUTH_AGE

        public static final String NET_TRAJANO_AUTH_AGE
        Age cookie name. The value of this cookie is an encrypted version of the IP Address and will expire based on the max age of the token.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • NET_TRAJANO_AUTH_ID

        public static final String NET_TRAJANO_AUTH_ID
        ID token cookie name. This one expires when the browser closes.

      • clientId

        private String clientId
        Client ID. This is set through "client.id" option.

      • clientSecret

        private String clientSecret
        Client secret. This is set through "client.secret" option.

      • cookieContext

        private String cookieContext
        Cookie context path. Set through through "cookie.context" option. This is optional.

      • handler

        private CallbackHandler handler
        Callback handler.

      • mandatory

        private boolean mandatory
        Flag to indicate that authentication is mandatory.

      • moduleOptions

        private Map<String,String> moduleOptions
        Options for the module.

      • redirectionEndpointUri

        private String redirectionEndpointUri
        Redirection endpoint URI. This is set through "redirection_endpoint" option. This must start with a forward slash. This value is optional.

      • restClient

        private javax.ws.rs.client.Client restClient
        REST Client. This is not final so a different one can be put in for testing.

      • scope

        private String scope
        Scope.

      • secret

        private SecretKey secret
        Secret key used for module level ciphers.

      • tokenUri

        private String tokenUri
        Token URI. This is set through "token_uri" option. This must start with a forward slash. This value is optional. The calling the token URI will return the contents of the JWT token object to the user. Make sure that this is intended before setting the value.

      • userInfoUri

        private String userInfoUri
        User info URI. This is set through "userinfo_uri" option. This must start with a forward slash. This value is optional. The calling the user info URI will return the contents of the user info object to the user. Make sure that this is intended before setting the value.

      • getRedirectionEndpointUri

        protected URI getRedirectionEndpointUri(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req)
        This gets the redirection endpoint URI.

        If the redirection endpoint URI option is not set then this gets the base URI for the application based on the request. This is used as the redirect URI for OAuth.

        If the redirection endpoint is set, then it is resolved against the request URL.

        Parameters:
        req - request
        Returns:
        redirection endpoint URI.

      • getRestClient

        protected javax.ws.rs.client.Client getRestClient()
        REST client.
        Returns:
        REST client

      • getSupportedMessageTypes

        public Class[] getSupportedMessageTypes()

        Supported message types. For our case we only need to deal with HTTP servlet request and responses. On Java EE 7 this will handle WebSockets as well.

        This creates a new array for security at the expense of performance.

        Specified by:
        getSupportedMessageTypes in interface javax.security.auth.message.module.ServerAuthModule
        Returns:
        HttpServletRequest and HttpServletResponse classes.

      • googleWorkaround

        private String googleWorkaround(String issuer)
        Workaround for the issuer value for Google. This was documented in 15.6.2. of the spec. In which case if the issuer does not start with https:// it will prepend it.
        Parameters:
        issuer - issuer
        Returns:
        updated issuer

      • isCallback

        public boolean isCallback(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req)
        Checks to see whether the ServerAuthModule is called by the resource owner. This is indicated by the presence of a code and a state on the URL and is an idempotent request (i.e. GET or HEAD). The resource owner would be a web browser that got a redirect sent by the OAuth 2.0 provider.
        Parameters:
        req - HTTP servlet request
        Returns:
        the module is called by the resource owner.

      • processTokenCookie

        private TokenCookie processTokenCookie(Subject subject,
                             javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req)
        Builds the token cookie and updates the subject principal and sets the user info attribute in the request. Any exceptions or validation problems during validation will make this return null to indicate that there was no valid token.
        Parameters:
        subject - subject
        req - servlet request
        Returns:
        token cookie.

      • redirectToAuthorizationEndpoint

        private javax.security.auth.message.AuthStatus redirectToAuthorizationEndpoint(javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest req,
                                                                     javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse resp)
                                                                        throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Sends a redirect to the authorization endpoint. It sends the current request URI as the state so that the user can be redirected back to the last place. However, this does not work for non-idempotent requests such as POST in those cases it will result in a 401 error and AuthStatus.SEND_FAILURE. For idempotent requests, it will build the redirect URI and return AuthStatus.SEND_CONTINUE.
        Parameters:
        req - HTTP servlet request
        resp - HTTP servlet response
        Returns:
        authentication status
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException

      • secureResponse

        public javax.security.auth.message.AuthStatus secureResponse(javax.security.auth.message.MessageInfo messageInfo,
                                                    Subject subject)
                                                      throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Return AuthStatus.SEND_SUCCESS.
        Specified by:
        secureResponse in interface javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth
        Parameters:
        messageInfo - contains the request and response messages. At this point the response message is already committed so nothing can be changed.
        subject - subject.
        Returns:
        AuthStatus.SEND_SUCCESS
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException

      • updateSubjectPrincipal

        private void updateSubjectPrincipal(Subject subject,
                          javax.json.JsonObject jwtPayload)
                             throws GeneralSecurityException
        Updates the principal for the subject. This is done through the callbacks.
        Parameters:
        subject - subject
        jwtPayload - JWT payload
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        GeneralSecurityException

      • validateRequest

        public javax.security.auth.message.AuthStatus validateRequest(javax.security.auth.message.MessageInfo messageInfo,
                                                     Subject clientSubject,
                                                     Subject serviceSubject)
                                                       throws javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
        Validates the request. The request must be secure otherwise it will return AuthStatus.FAILURE. It then tries to build the token cookie data if available, if the token is valid, subject is set correctly and user info data if present is stored in the request, then call HTTP method specific operations.
        Specified by:
        validateRequest in interface javax.security.auth.message.ServerAuth
        Parameters:
        messageInfo - request and response
        clientSubject - client subject
        serviceSubject - service subject, ignored.
        Returns:
        Auth status
        Throws:
        javax.security.auth.message.AuthException
